Description: Lower rim and body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery kylix; interior glazed black. Exterior: at junction of reserved rim and bowl, two thin bands; below, black-figure decoration consisting of hoplites advancing to right (tip of spear of warrior to left, then upper body of two warriors, one on right with bell corslet and both wearing a Corinthian helmet, holding a spear in their right hand and a round shield on their left arm); between the two, bird flying to right; dot rosette and dotted cross as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 121, pl. XXXVII, no. 341.2)
Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 340) (Incorrectly labels the sherd as coming from a column krater)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.258) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.6008 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
